questions.text: Match the following:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A2, B1, C3, D4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Medialisation thyroplasty — 2. Unilateral VC palsy : This is a surgical procedure used to treat unilateral vocal cord palsy . By moving the paralyzed vocal cord medially, the voice and airway protection during swallowing can be improved.
  • • Option A. Medialisation thyroplasty — 2. Unilateral VC palsy
  • • unilateral vocal cord palsy
  • • Option B. Lateralisation thyroplasty — 1. Bilateral VC palsy : This procedure is used in cases of bilateral vocal cord palsy where both vocal cords are paralyzed in the midline. Lateralization helps to open the airway to prevent airway obstruction.
  • • Option B. Lateralisation thyroplasty — 1. Bilateral VC palsy
  • • bilateral vocal cord palsy
  • • Option C. Shortening thyroplasty — 3. Puberphonia : This procedure is used to treat puberphonia (a condition where males retain a high-pitched voice after puberty). Shortening the vocal cords lowers the pitch of the voice.
  • • Option C. Shortening thyroplasty — 3. Puberphonia
  • • puberphonia
  • • Option D. Lengthening thyroplasty — 4. Androphonia : This procedure is used to treat androphonia (a deep, low-pitched voice in females). Lengthening the vocal cords raises the pitch of the voice.
  • • Option D. Lengthening thyroplasty — 4. Androphonia
  • • androphonia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Medialisation thyroplasty is used for unilateral vocal cord palsy to improve vocal quality and prevent aspiration. Lateralisation thyroplasty is used for bilateral vocal cord palsy to open the airway. Shortening thyroplasty is used to correct puberphonia by lowering the pitch of the voice. Lengthening thyroplasty is used to correct androphonia by raising the pitch of the voice.
  • ➤ Medialisation thyroplasty is used for unilateral vocal cord palsy to improve vocal quality and prevent aspiration.

  • ➤ Lengthening thyroplasty is used to correct androphonia by raising the pitch of the voice.
  • ➤ Lengthening thyroplasty
  • ➤ androphonia

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with itching and discomfort in his right ear for the past week. He also complains of mild hearing loss. On examination, the ear canal appears erythematous with white, fluffy material. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presented with hardness of hearing in both ears from last 5 years which was gradually deteriorating. On otoscopy, tympanic membrane looked normal. questions.explanation:
Ans. C.

questions.text: High risk of aspiration is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bilateral SLN palsy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Bilateral Superior Laryngeal Nerve (SLN) palsy : The SLN provides sensory innervation to the supraglottic region, including the area above the vocal cords. In cases of bilateral SLN palsy , the sensation above the vocal cords is lost , leading to a high risk of aspiration because the patient cannot sense foreign material in the airway and cannot trigger a protective cough reflex. As a result, food, liquid, or secretions may enter the airway without being detected, leading to aspiration.
  • • Bilateral Superior Laryngeal Nerve (SLN) palsy : The SLN provides sensory innervation to the supraglottic region, including the area above the vocal cords. In cases of bilateral SLN palsy , the sensation above the vocal cords is lost , leading to a high risk of aspiration because the patient cannot sense foreign material in the airway and cannot trigger a protective cough reflex. As a result, food, liquid, or secretions may enter the airway without being detected, leading to aspiration.
  • • Bilateral Superior Laryngeal Nerve (SLN) palsy
  • • SLN
  • • sensory innervation
  • • supraglottic
  • • bilateral SLN palsy
  • • sensation above the vocal cords is lost
  • • aspiration
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Unilateral SLN palsy : In unilateral SLN palsy, only one side loses sensation, but the opposite side can still compensate, so the risk of aspiration is lower compared to bilateral SLN palsy.
  • • Option A. Unilateral SLN palsy
  • • Option C. Unilateral RLN palsy : The Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve (RLN) supplies motor innervation to most of the muscles that control the vocal cords. In unilateral RLN palsy, one vocal cord is paralyzed, which can cause hoarseness or mild swallowing difficulties, but aspiration risk is not as high as with sensory loss from SLN palsy.
  • • Option C. Unilateral RLN palsy
  • • Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve (RLN)
  • • aspiration risk is not as high
  • • Option D. Bilateral RLN palsy : In bilateral RLN palsy, both vocal cords are paralyzed, often in a midline position, leading to potential airway obstruction , but the risk of aspiration is not as high as with bilateral SLN palsy, because the sensory function remains intact .
  • • Option D. Bilateral RLN palsy
  • • airway obstruction
  • • sensory function remains intact

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bilateral SLN palsy poses a high risk of aspiration due to the loss of sensation in the supraglottic region, preventing detection of foreign material in the airway and inhibiting the protective cough reflex.
  • ➤ Bilateral SLN palsy
  • ➤ high risk of aspiration
  • ➤ sensation
